byline.original: By PATRICK McGEEHAN and AL BAKER

abstract: New York City investigators theorize that attempt to hide unauthorized siphoning of natural gas may have caused East Village explosion that destroyed three buildings and killed two men; suspect landlord Maria Hrynenko may have instructed residents on how to answer Consolidated Edison workers' questions about gas service; unproven theory is based on interviews with witnesses, utility workers and manager of ground floor restaurant.
lead_paragraph: The unproven theory is that siphoning equipment was dismantled or hidden when inspectors visited on Thursday, and that an attempt to resume the tapping led to the fatal explosion.

headline.main: East Village Explosion Might Have Followed Attempt to Hide Gas Siphoning
headline.print_headline: East Village Blast Might Have Followed Attempt to Hide Gas Siphoning

snippet: The unproven theory is that siphoning equipment was dismantled or hidden when inspectors visited on Thursday, and that an attempt to resume the tapping led to the fatal explosion.
